statements.name: PROC FORMAT
statements.description: Creates user-specified formats and informats for variables.

arguments.name: CASFMTLIB=
arguments.description: adds a format library to a CAS session.

arguments.name: CNTLIN=
arguments.description: specifies a SAS data set from which PROC FORMAT builds informats or formats.

arguments.name: CNTLOUT=
arguments.description: creates a SAS data set that stores information about informats or formats that are contained in the catalog specified in the LIBRARY= option.

arguments.name: FMTLIB
arguments.description: prints information about informats or formats in the catalog that is specified in the LIBRARY= option.

arguments.name: LIBRARY=
arguments.description: specifies a SAS library or catalog that contains the informats or formats that you are creating in the PROC FORMAT step.

arguments.name: LOCALE
arguments.description: specifies to create a format catalog that corresponds to the current SAS locale.

arguments.name: MAXLABLEN=
arguments.description: specifies the number of characters of the informatted or formatted value that appear in PROC FORMAT output.

arguments.name: MAXSELEN=
arguments.description: specifies the number of characters of the start and end values that appear in the PROC FORMAT output.

arguments.name: NOREPLACE
arguments.description: prevents a new informat or format from replacing an existing one of the same name.

arguments.name: PAGE
arguments.description: prints information about each format and informat in the catalog.

statements.name: EXCLUDE
statements.description: Excludes entries from processing by the FMTLIB and CNTLOUT= options.

arguments.name: entry
arguments.description: specifies one or more catalog entries to exclude from processing. Catalog entry names are the same as the name of the informat or format that they store. Because informats and formats can have the same name, and because character and numeric informats or formats can have the same name, you must use certain prefixes when specifying informats and formats in the EXCLUDE statement. Follow these rules when specifying entries in the EXCLUDE statement: • Precede names of entries that contain character formats with a dollar sign ($). • Precede names of entries that contain character informats with an at sign and a dollar sign (for example, @$entry-name). • Precede names of entries that contain numeric informats with an at sign (@). • Specify names of entries that contain numeric formats without a prefix.

statements.name: INVALUE
statements.description: Creates an informat for reading and converting raw data values.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: names the informat that you are creating.

arguments.name: DEFAULT=
arguments.description: specifies the default length of the informat.

arguments.name: FUZZ=
arguments.description: specifies a fuzz factor for matching values to a range.

arguments.name: JUST
arguments.description: left-justifies all input strings before they are compared to ranges.

arguments.name: MAX=
arguments.description: specifies a maximum length for the informat.

arguments.name: MIN=
arguments.description: specifies a minimum length for the informat.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: stores values or ranges in the order in which you define them.

arguments.name: REGEXP
arguments.description: specifies that the preceding range is to be treated as a Perl regular expression.

arguments.name: REGEXPE
arguments.description: specifies that the preceding range is to be treated as a Perl regular expression.

arguments.name: UPCASE
arguments.description: upper cases all input strings before they are compared to ranges.

arguments.name: value-or-range
arguments.description: See .

arguments.name: 'character-string'
arguments.description: is a character string up to 32,767 characters long. Typically, character-string becomes the value of a character variable when you use the informat to convert raw data. Use character-string for informatted-value only when you are creating a character informat. If you omit the single or double quotation marks around character-string, then the INVALUE statement assumes that the quotation marks are there.

arguments.name: number
arguments.description: is a number that becomes the informatted value. Typically, number becomes the value of a numeric variable when you use the informat to convert raw data. Use number for informatted-value when you are creating a numeric informat. The maximum for number depends on the host operating environment.

arguments.name: _ERROR_
arguments.description: treats data values in the designated range as invalid data. SAS assigns a missing value to the variable, prints the data line in the SAS log, and issues a warning message.

arguments.name: _SAME_
arguments.description: prevents the informat from converting the raw data as any other value. For example, the following GROUP. informat converts values 01 through 20 and assigns the numbers 1 through 20 as the result. All other values are assigned a missing value.

arguments.name: existing-informat
arguments.description: is an informat that is supplied by SAS or an existing user-defined informat. The informat that you are creating uses the existing informat to convert the raw data that match value-or-range on the left side of the equal sign. If you use an existing informat, then enclose the informat name in square brackets (for example, [date9.]) or with parentheses and vertical bars (for example, (|date9.|)). Do not enclose the name of the existing informat in single quotation marks.

statements.name: PICTURE
statements.description: Creates a template for printing numbers.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: names the format that you are creating.

arguments.name: DATATYPE=
arguments.description: enables the use of directives in the picture as a template to format date, time, or datetime values.

arguments.name: DEFAULT=
arguments.description: specifies the default length of the picture.

arguments.name: DECSEP=
arguments.description: specifies the separator character for the fractional part of a number.

arguments.name: DIG3SEP=
arguments.description: specifies the three-digit separator character for a number.

arguments.name: FILL=
arguments.description: specifies a character that completes the formatted value.

arguments.name: FUZZ=
arguments.description: specifies a fuzz factor for matching values to a range.

arguments.name: LANGUAGE=
arguments.description: specifies the language that is used for weekdays and months that you can substitute in a date, time, or datetime picture.

arguments.name: MAX=
arguments.description: specifies a maximum length for the format.

arguments.name: MIN=
arguments.description: specifies a minimum length for the format.

arguments.name: MULTILABEL
arguments.description: enables the assignment of labels to multiple values-or-range values that might have the same or overlapping values.

arguments.name: MULTIPLIER=
arguments.description: specifies a number to multiply the variable's value by before it is formatted.

arguments.name: NOEDIT
arguments.description: specifies that numbers are message characters rather than digit selectors.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: stores values or ranges in the order in which you define them.

arguments.name: PREFIX=
arguments.description: specifies a character prefix to place in front of the formatted value.

arguments.name: ROUND
arguments.description: rounds the value to the nearest integer before formatting.

arguments.name: value-or-range
arguments.description: See .

arguments.name: digit
arguments.description: are numeric characters (0 through 9) that define positions for numeric values. A picture format with nonzero-digit selectors prints any leading zeros in variable values; picture digit selectors of 0 do not print leading zeros in variable values. If the picture format contains digit selectors, then a digit selector must be the first character in the picture.

arguments.name: message
arguments.description: are nonnumeric characters that are printed as specified in the picture. The following PICTURE statement contains both digit selectors (99) and message characters (illegal day value). Because the DAYS. format has nonzero-digit selectors, values are printed with leading zeros. The special range OTHER prints the message characters for any values that do not fall into the specified range (1 through 31).

arguments.name: %a
arguments.description: abbreviated weekday name (for example, Wed).

arguments.name: %A
arguments.description: full weekday name (for example, Wednesday).

arguments.name: %b
arguments.description: abbreviated month name (for example, JAN or Jan).

the full month name (for example, January) if n is not included in the directive. n specifies the number of characters that appear for the month name. In comparison, the %b directive writes a three-character month abbreviation in uppercase letters for some locales.

arguments.name: %C
arguments.description: long month name with blank padding (January through December) (for example, December).

arguments.name: %d
arguments.description: day of the month.

arguments.name: %e
arguments.description: day of the month as a two-character decimal number with leading spaces (" 1"- "31") (for example, “ 2”).

arguments.name: %F
arguments.description: full weekday name with blank padding.

arguments.name: %G
arguments.description: year as a four-digit decimal number (for example, 2008). If the week that contains January 1 has four or more days in the new year, then it is considered week 1 in the new year. Otherwise, it is the last week of the previous year and the year is considered the previous year.

arguments.name: %H
arguments.description: hour (24-hour clock).

arguments.name: %I
arguments.description: hour (12-hour clock).

arguments.name: %j
arguments.description: day of the year as a decimal number (1–366), with leading zero.

arguments.name: %m
arguments.description: month (1–12).

arguments.name: %M
arguments.description: minute (0–59).

arguments.name: %n
arguments.description: number of days in a duration as a decimal number (maximum of 10 digits) (for example, 25).

arguments.name: %o
arguments.description: month (1-12) with blank padding (for example, " 2").

arguments.name: %p
arguments.description: equivalent to either a.m. or p.m.

arguments.name: %q
arguments.description: abbreviated quarter of the year string such as 1, 2, 3, or 4.

arguments.name: %Q
arguments.description: quarter of the year string, such as Quarter1, Quarter2, Quarter3, or Quarter4.

arguments.name: %s
arguments.description: fractional seconds as decimal digits (for example, .39555). The number of digits formatted is the number of digits to the right of the decimal point that is specified when you use the format. SAS rounds fractional seconds to accommodate the number of digits specified for fractional seconds.

arguments.name: %S
arguments.description: seconds (0–59), allowing for possible leap seconds.

arguments.name: %u
arguments.description: weekday as a one-digit decimal number (1–7 (Monday - Sunday)) (for example, Sunday=7).

arguments.name: %U
arguments.description: week number of the year as a decimal number (0–53). Sunday is considered the first day of the week.

arguments.name: %V
arguments.description: week number (01–53) with the first Monday as the start day of the first week. Minimum days of the first week is 4.

arguments.name: %w
arguments.description: weekday as a one-digit decimal number (0–6 (Sunday through Saturday)) (for example, Sunday=0).

arguments.name: %W
arguments.description: week number (0–53) with the first Monday as the start day of the first week.

arguments.name: %y
arguments.description: year without century (0–99) (for example, 93).

arguments.name: %Y
arguments.description: year with century as a four-digit decimal number (1970–2069) (for example, 1994).

arguments.name: %z
arguments.description: UTC time-zone offset.

arguments.name: %Z
arguments.description: time-zone name.
the % character.

statements.name: SELECT
statements.description: Selects entries for processing by the FMTLIB and CNTLOUT= options.

arguments.name: entry
arguments.description: specifies one or more catalog entries for processing. Catalog entry names are the same as the name of the informat or format that they store. Because informats and formats can have the same name, and because character and numeric informats or formats can have the same name, you must use certain prefixes when specifying informats and formats in the SELECT statement. Follow these rules when specifying entries in the SELECT statement: • Precede names of entries that contain character formats with a dollar sign ($). • Precede names of entries that contain character informats with an at sign and a dollar sign (for example, @$entry-name). • Precede names of entries that contain numeric informats with an at sign (@). • Specify names of entries that contain numeric formats without a prefix.

statements.name: VALUE
statements.description: Creates a format that specifies character strings to use to print variable values.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: names the format that you are creating. If you created a function using the FCMP procedure to use as a format, name is the function name without parenthesis.

arguments.name: DEFAULT=
arguments.description: specifies the default length of the format.

arguments.name: FUZZ=
arguments.description: specifies a fuzz factor for matching values to a range.

arguments.name: MAX=
arguments.description: specifies a maximum length for the format.

arguments.name: MIN=
arguments.description: specifies a minimum length for the format.

arguments.name: MULTILABEL
arguments.description: enables the assignment of multiple labels or external values to internal values.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: stores values or ranges in the order in which you define them.

arguments.name: value-or-range
arguments.description: For details about how to specify value-or-range, see .

arguments.name: formatted-value
arguments.description: specifies a character string that becomes the printed value of the variable value that appears on the left side of the equal sign. Formatted values are always character strings, regardless of whether you are creating a character or numeric format.

arguments.name: existing-format
arguments.description: specifies a format that is supplied by SAS or an existing user-defined format. The format that you are creating uses the existing format to convert the raw data that is a match for value-or-range on the left side of the equal sign.

arguments.name: functionname
arguments.description: specifies a function that is supplied by SAS or an existing user-defined function.
